tossups.question: Description acceptable. The first evidence for this event comes from a discussion of a “sentry-box” in a letter to Peter Collinson, who discussed this event at the Royal Society. George Richmann at the University of St. Petersburg died trying to replicate this event in 1753. A future Loyalist Governor assisted in this event according to details related by (*) Joseph Priestley. Equipment used in this event included a protective wax handle and some hemp string connected to a Leyden jar. Thomas Dalibard replicated this experiment in France, where its originator would serve as an ambassador. This experiment was originally to be done atop a church spire in Philadelphia. For 10 points, name this 1752 experiment involving a Founding Father and a storm.
tossups.answer: Benjamin Franklin’s kite experiment [accept anything involving Benjamin Franklin’s electricity experiment or Ben Franklin and the kite experiment; accept Benjamin Franklin “discovering” electricity; prompt on kite experiment or electricity experiment or lightning experiment or other partial answer] (Though acceptable here, Franklin “discovering” electricity is a misleading description.)
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~25887~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

tossups.question: This country’s resilience is often symbolized by a war-damaged modernist cinema in the Martyrs’ Square region of its capital nicknamed The Egg. When the only major landfill in this country shut down in the 2010s, garbage piled high in its Chouf Mountains. The medieval Castle of Gibelet is a tourist attraction in a port city in this country that lends its name to the Greek word for (*) papyrus. A 700-year-old mummy nicknamed Yasmine was originally from this modern day country’s Maronite community. This country, whose city of Byblos was once a Phoenician hub, has a flag that depicts one of its historically important cedar trees. For 10 points, name this Middle Eastern country with capital at Beirut.
tossups.answer: Lebanon [or Republic of Lebanon; or Lebanese Republic]
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, Geography - World> ~23292~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

tossups.question: This work describes a man waiting at a vestibule as one who made “the great refusal.” Dorothy Sayers tried to preserve this work’s rhyme scheme in a project a century after it was translated by Henry Wadsworth Longfellow. A couple in this work euphemistically describes love-making with the phrase “we read no more that day,” after reading a book about Lancelot and Guinevere. This work’s narrator declares (*) “midway upon the journey of our life / I found myself within a forest dark” before seeing a leopard, a lion, and a she-wolf. In this terza rima (“TUR-zuh REE-muh”) poem, the narrator meets Paolo and Francesca and sees a gate marked “Abandon all hope, ye who enter here.” For 10 points, Dante tours Hell, Purgatory, and Paradise in what poem?
tossups.answer: The Divine Comedy [or Divina Commedia; accept Inferno or Purgatorio or Paradiso; accept Purgatory or Paradise before mention; prompt on the Comedy or Commedia]
tossups.metadata: Jaimie Carlson, Literature - European - Poetry> ~27541~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson

tossups.question: Three of these devices form a negative feedback loop in the Wilson current mirror. Two of these devices are biased with the same current in modern differential, or “long-tailed,” pairs. These devices can exhibit a small-signal output resistance due to the Early effect, which is represented by adding a resistor to the hybrid-pi model. A type of these devices transitions from (*) triode mode to saturation mode when the voltage between the gate and the drain exceeds a threshold. These devices come in “bipolar junction” and “field-effect” types. The number of these devices in an IC doubles every year according to Moore’s law. For 10 points, name these semiconductor devices that act as three-terminal switches or amplifiers.
tossups.answer: transistors [accept metal-oxide-semiconductor field-effect transistors or bipolar junction transistors or MOSFETs or BJTs; prompt on T]
tossups.metadata: Benjamin Chapman, Science - Physics> ~28171~ <Editor: David Bass

tossups.question: Studies of this archaeological site coined koulourai as a term for bread-shaped pits. Piet de Jong restored frescos of dolphins at this site, where Theodore Fyfe barely restored the Shrines of the Double Axes. A gypsum throne at this site was surrounded by a fresco of a griffin. Figurines created at this site depict women with bare breasts and holding (*) snakes in their hands. This site’s 1450 BCE destruction has been attributed either to an eruption on Thera or to a Mycenaean invasion, as evidenced by Linear B script. At this site, stucco panels of women leaping over bulls were studied by Sir Arthur Evans. For 10 points, name this Minoan palace complex on Crete that legendarily contained the Minotaur’s labyrinth.
tossups.answer: Knossos [or Gnossus; or Cnossus; accept the palace at Knossos; accept Palace of Minos until “Minoan” is read; prompt on labyrinth; prompt on Crete]
tossups.metadata: Ganon Evans, History - European - Classical> ~27660~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

tossups.question: J. R. Monterose and Jackie McLean use their saxophones to imitate foghorns and cars on this musician’s cover of Gershwin’s “A Foggy Day.” That song appears on a 1956 album by this musician whose cover depicts a white, orange, and black humanoid figure. Long, one-chord vamps performed by this musician’s Jazz Workshop were developed into tracks like (*) “Haitian Fight Song.” An album by this artist is titled after the original scientific name of Java Man. This musician, who titled one album after his last name five times, included “Fables of Faubus” on a 1959 album that also contains an elegy to Lester Young titled “Goodbye Pork Pie Hat.” For 10 points, name this eccentric jazz bassist that recorded an album titled “[him] Ah Um.”
tossups.answer: Charles Mingus [or Charles Mingus Jr.]
tossups.metadata: Victor Pavao, Fine Arts - Jazz

tossups.question: Specific answer required. Joe Sutter wrote a memoir titled for building these machines at a breakneck schedule with a team dubbed “the Incredibles.” The Pratt & Whitney JT9D was first designed for these machines. These machines’ unique shape stemmed from Juan Trippe’s requirement to Bill Allen that they be nose-loading. The largest building in the world by volume is a factory in (*) Everett, Washington built to manufacture these machines. The high-bypass turbofan engine was designed for these machines. A stretch “X” improvement to these machines was scrapped in favor of the Dreamliner. The original variant of these machines had a short upper deck used as a lounge by Pan Am. For 10 points, name these iconic early jumbo jets manufactured by Boeing.
tossups.answer: Boeing 747 [accept specific types of the 747 like the 747-200; prompt on non-specific answers like airplane or passenger jet or jumbo jet; prompt on Boeings or Boeing planes]
tossups.metadata: Lalit Maharjan, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~25480~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

tossups.question: A race of “little people” in this region miraculously constructed roads and temples overnight for the price of one shrimp. In this region, mortals lacking a merciful ancestor must strip naked and lie motionless to avoid death upon sighting the nightmarchers. ’Alae (“uh-LAH-ay”) feathers sacred to Hina decorated an object used to create this region. This region’s snow goddess wins a sled race against a goddess who turned the dancer (*) Hopoe (“ho-PO-ay”) to stone after her sister Hi’iaka (“hee-ee-AH-kuh”) failed to return after 40 days. It’s not New Zealand, but a trickster demigod names an island he fished up in this archipelago, whose native deities include Pele (“PAY-lay”). For 10 points, name this archipelago whose islands include one named for Māui.
tossups.answer: Hawai’i [or the Hawaiian Islands; prompt on Maui until read by asking “what archipelago is it part of?; prompt on O’ahu or Kaua’i or Moloka’i or Lana’i or Ni’iahu or Kaho’olawe by asking “what archipelago is it part of?”; prompt on Polynesia; prompt on the Pacific Ocean] (The first line discusses the Menehune; the ’alae feathers are used as bait.)
tossups.metadata: Kevin Thomas, RMP - World Mythology> ~27592~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

tossups.question: A girl remembers this character’s advice to “delete the adjectives and…have the facts” as she watches her brother do an Egyptian dance. This character advises a child that “you never really understand a person…until you climb into his skin and walk around in it.” This character describes “real courage” as “when you know you’re licked before you begin but you begin anyway” while discussing the elderly (*) morphine addict Miss Dubose. This character, who is nicknamed “One-Shot,” explains “the one thing that doesn’t abide by majority rule is a person’s conscience” as he takes up Tom Robinson’s legal defense. For 10 points, name this lawyer and father of Scout and Jem Finch in To Kill a Mockingbird.
tossups.answer: Atticus Finch [prompt on Finch]
tossups.metadata: Ganon Evans, Literature - American - Long Fiction> ~28421~ <Editor: Chandler West

tossups.question: In October 2024, Kevin Buzzard will begin a five-year project to formalize an instance of this task as part of the Xena Project. Calc, term, conv, and tactic modes are used to verify this task with the software Lean, a competitor of Coq (“coke”). “W·L·O·G” is used to justify arbitrary choices in this task. Appel and Haken checked 1,834 (*) cases in the earliest significant instance of using computers for this task. A method or example is provided by constructive instances of this task that may be performed via exhaustion, induction, or contradiction. This task is performed in two columns with statements like “S·A·S” and “SSS” in typical geometry curricula. For 10 points, name this task of demonstrating a mathematical truth.
tossups.answer: proof-writing [accept equivalents, like proving a mathematical statement; accept word forms of formal proof or proof verification or proof verifier or proof assistant or theorem prover or computer-assisted proof or proof by exhaustion or proof by induction or proof by contradiction] (Kevin Buzzard received a million-pound grant to formalize Fermat’s last theorem in Lean.)
tossups.metadata: David Bass, Science - Math> ~27340~ <Editor: David Bass

tossups.question: A best-selling 1989 recording of these pieces was by the “punk,” foot-stamping classical musician Nigel Kennedy. In 2012, Daniel Hope premiered a “recomposed” version of these pieces by Max Richter. The philosopher Jean-Jacques Rousseau transcribed one of these pieces for solo flute. In the third of these pieces, the harpsichord depicts dancing (*) drunkards who fall asleep. The first of these pieces features a two-note viola motif representing a barking dog, and the second ends with a thunderstorm, as described in their accompanying sonnets. The first third of The Contest Between Harmony and Invention comprises, for 10 points, what set of violin concertos by Antonio Vivaldi that include “Autumn” and “Spring”?
tossups.answer: The Four Seasons [or Le quattro stagioni; prompt on Vivaldi violin concertos; prompt on The Contest Between Harmony and Invention or Il cimento dell’armonia e dell’inventione before read]
tossups.metadata: Steven Yuan, Fine Arts - Music - Baroque> ~25564~ <Editor: Ivvone Zhou

tossups.question: This quantity is assumed to be independent of pressure to eliminate the integral from a liquid’s Poynting factor. This quantity is assumed to be negligibly small for liquids to derive the Clausius–Clapeyron equation. When ethanol and water are mixed 50-50, this quantity decreases by 3 percent compared to an ideal solution. This quantity for the liquid and vapor are two of the three roots of the (*) van der Waals equation. If this quantity is constant, the First Law reduces to “delta U equals Q,” since no work is done. For water, this extensive quantity is minimized at four degrees, and it unusually increases upon freezing. For 10 points, what quantity is measured from the bottom of the meniscus in a graduated cylinder?
tossups.answer: volume [or molar volume or specific volume; prompt on V; reject “density”]
tossups.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Chemistry> ~27563~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

tossups.question: This poem’s first three words title a Stephen Vincent Benét story in which an emperor reads this poem on his deathbed. This poem’s epitaph describes a youth who gave to Misery “all he had, a tear” and got from Heaven “all he wished, a friend.” In this poem’s setting, a “hoary-headed swain” points out an engraving to “a youth to Fortune and to Fame unknown.” This poem describes how “the (*) paths of glory lead but to the grave” before wondering if “some mute inglorious Milton” lies in this poem’s setting. This poem describes a place “far from the madding crowd’s ignoble strife” where “The curfew tolls the knell of parting day.” For 10 points, name this Thomas Gray poem set in a rural cemetery.
tossups.answer: “Elegy Written in a Country Churchyard” [prompt on Gray’s Elegy before “Gray”] (The story is “The Curfew Tolls.”)
tossups.metadata: Jaimie Carlson, Literature - British - Poetry> ~26115~ <Editor: Jim Fan

tossups.question: Settlement to this region was prevented by a 600-mile long series of trees and ditches known as the Willow Palisade. Indigenous inhabitants of this region’s Sixty-Four Villages included the Daur people, who were targeted by mounted bandits called hónghúzi. The Lytton Report denounced an invasion of this region that occurred under the pretext of a (*) false flag operation to blow up a railway. This region is named after a people who organized under the Eight Banners and were led by the Aisin-Gioro clan. A puppet government established in this region was led by the last Qīng Emperor, Pǔyí. Port Arthur and Mukden are cities in, for 10 points, what region in Northeast China that Japan invaded in 1931?
tossups.answer: Manchuria [or Mǎnzhōu; accept Manchukuo; prompt on Northeast China or China until read; prompt on Heilongjiang or Jilin or Liaoning Province; prompt on Hulunbuir or Hinggan or Tongliao or Chifeng or Xilin Gol]
tossups.metadata: Jeffrey Liu, History - World - Asian> ~28147~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

tossups.question: In a play, this character first appears dumping trash at the feet of a statue called a “God of Death.” In one adaptation, this character mocks the idea of recognizing someone from his footprints or clothes and instead recognizes him from a scar from chasing a deer. In a 1943 play, this character accepts guilt as an example of “bad faith” and is chased off stage by a buzzing sound. While this character is giving (*) libations to a grave, she recognizes a stranger after finding a lock of hair. This character dances in a white gown on top of a cave in Jean-Paul Sartre’s The Flies. For 10 points, name this character who plots with her brother to kill their mother Clytemnestra in Aeschylus’s Oresteia (“or-eh-STY-uh”).
tossups.answer: Electra (The first line is The Flies. The second line is from Euripides.)
tossups.metadata: Jim Fan, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~28075~ <Editor: Jim Fan

tossups.question: Description acceptable. During this event, a figure who conquers and rules over Syria for nine months is swallowed up by the desert of Bayda. During this event, a worm eats at the napes of two figures who dig past a wall strengthened by iron and molten lead. Moses’s rod and Solomon’s seal are possessed by a figure who emerges from the hill of Safa during this event to destroy the noses of (*) nonbelievers. A saffron-robed figure descends on Damascus during this event, which is portended by the release of Yajuj, Majuj, and the Beast of the Earth. During this event, Jesus aids the Mahdi against the Dajjal, the deceitful Messiah. For 10 points, Islamic eschatology is the study of what time when the dead shall be resurrected and every person judged?
tossups.answer: the end times [or the end of days or the apocalypse or armageddon or the end of the world or universe; or Akhir al-Zamān; accept Judgment Day, Resurrection Day, and the Last Day; prompt on the coming of the Mahdi and the coming of the twelfth imam or the coming of Jesus; prompt on the Rapture] (The first line refers to the Sufyani)

tossups.question: During this decade, 250,000 private citizens joined the government-sponsored American Protective League. A bill in this decade was near-unanimously passed except for a sole dissenting vote from Meyer London. In this decade, Congress refused to seat Wisconsin representative Victor Berger, and the Statue of Liberty was damaged in the Black Tom explosion. An activist was arrested in this decade after a speech made in (*) Canton, Ohio. That activist, like Alexander Berkman and Emma Goldman, was prosecuted under an Espionage Act passed in this decade. A president was re-elected in this decade on the campaign slogan “He Kept Us Out of War.” For 10 points, name this decade where the Zimmerman Telegram helped bring the US into World War I.
tossups.answer: 1910s [prompt on the 10s]
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - American - 1865-1945> ~27096~ <Editor: Arjun Nageswaran

tossups.question: A misplaced velamentous insertion of this structure often results in vasa previa. A vein carrying oxygenated blood through this structure is shunted into the ductus venosus to avoid the liver. Instead of adventitia, this structure’s two arteries are surrounded by Wharton’s jelly. A flexible “nuchal” (“NOO-cull”) type of this structure can cause asphyxiation. Since HSCs and MSCs harvested from this structure are (*) safer than bone marrow stem cells for transplants, its blood is banked for long-term “biological insurance.” This structure connects the amniotic sac to the placenta, and a stump left over by clamping it creates a scar at the navel. For 10 points, what tube carrying blood from a mother to her fetus is cut at birth?
tossups.answer: umbilical cord [accept umbilical cord blood or cord blood or UCB; prompt on umbilical or cord by itself; reject “umbilicus”]
tossups.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Biology> ~28211~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

tossups.question: This is the first word in the title of a book that claims all propositions are analytic, strongly verifiable, or weakly verifiable. A namesake hypothesis by Jerry Fodor posits that mental representations have the structure of these systems. The study of these systems names a “turn” that often marks the start of analytic philosophy. These systems are governed by a set of (*) family resemblances according to a book that diverges from its author’s earlier picture theory. These systems, which appear with “truth” and “logic” in the title of a book by A. J. Ayer, cannot be private according to Philosophical Investigations. For 10 points, Ludwig Wittgenstein theorized games surrounding what systems of verbal communication?
tossups.answer: languages [accept Language, Truth, and Logic; accept The Language of Thought; accept linguistic turn; accept language games; accept sprachspiel; accept private languages]
tossups.metadata: Forrest Weintraub, RMP - Philosophy> ~28092~ <Editor: Vincent Du

tossups.question: One artist added mica powder to this technique so his paintings of “beautiful” women viewing themselves in mirrors would sparkle. In the 1700s, colorful “brocade pictures” using this technique depicted newspaper scenes. Small rectangles appeared on a “key” object used in this technique to line up colors. An artwork created through this technique depicts the dark peak of a mountain by fading (*) Prussian blue dyes. A disc-like tool called a baren is pressed against washi paper in a style of this technique called mokuhanga. Ukiyo-e artworks like Hokusai’s Thirty-Six Views of Mount Fuji were made using, for 10 points, what technique in which a design is chiseled into a namesake material then pressed into an artwork?
tossups.answer: woodblock printing [accept mokuhanga until read; prompt on printing; prompt on woodblocks or woodcuts or wood; prompt on ukiyo-e or Ōkubi-e with “What technique was used to make those artworks?”] (The lead-in is about Utamaro.)

tossups.question: Description acceptable. NGOs working on this problem launched the “U=U” (“U equals U”) campaign that seeks to get an IPR rate of 0.03 by 2030. Zeda Rosenberg founded the non-profit IPM to help alleviate this problem with initiatives such as a dapivirine silicone ring. In 2023, Congress cut funding for a widely-hailed program combating this problem launched by George W. Bush called PEPFAR, whose initiatives included treating 750,000 women with products such as (*) Truvada. In the 2000s, some NGOs working on this problem were slowed by the Denialist policies of Thabo Mbeki in South Africa. For 10 points, name this ongoing problem addressed through programs such as “abstinence, be faithful, use a condom” and antiretroviral drugs.
tossups.answer: AIDS epidemic [or HIV epidemic; accept anything mentioning HIV or AIDS including the AIDS epidemic in Sub-Saharan Africa; accept answers such as treating or curing or preventing or eradicating AIDS or HIV; prompt on answers such as preventing the spread of STDs or sexually transmitted diseases or STIs or sexually transmitted infections or venereal diseases or diseases; prompt on epidemic] (IPR stands for incidence:prevalence ratio.)
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, Current Events - World> ~27547~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

bonuses.leadin: When this system’s angle is zero, velocity squared cannot exceed the product of r, mu, and little g, where mu is the coefficient of friction. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this system in which an object moves in an arc along an inclined surface.
Solving a banked turn system involves equating components of this force with weight and centripetal acceleration. This force acts out from, and perpendicular to, a surface.

The angle below which no positive velocity maintains a trajectory around a banked turn is given by this function of mu, since maximum velocity squared is proportional to sine-theta plus mu-cosine-theta. Your answer should not be signed.
answers: banked turn [or banked curve or banked roadway; accept banking in place of “banked”; prompt on a turn; prompt on banked]
bonuses.metadata: David Bass, Science - Physics> ~23758~ <Editor: David Bass

bonuses.leadin: In 2019, a hate group named for the Saw franchise published a list targeting queer activists in this country. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country whose Anti-Corruption Foundation released a 2021 documentary about the secret “Palace” of its leader.
A 2020 constitutional amendment made this practice more restrictive in Russia. The 2015 Obergefell decision legalized the same-sex form of this practice in the US.

Vladimir Kosarevsky fled Russia for refusing to destroy items violating “traditional values” in one of these institutions in Moscow. The ALA has chronicled the efforts of Moms for Liberty to challenge US examples of these institutions.
answers: Russia [or Russian Federation] (The Anti-Corruption Foundation was founded by Alexei Navalny.)
marriage [accept gay marriage or same-sex marriage; accept synonyms such as matrimony]
public libraries [accept public school libraries or research libraries; prompt on public schools; reject “book stores”]
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, Current Events - World> ~23323~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

bonuses.leadin: In this religion, karma’s accumulation on the soul is frequently analogized to dust gathering on a wet cloth. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this South Asian religion whose Digambara (“dig-GUM-buh-ruh”) and Śvētāmbara (“shvay-TAHM-buh-ruh”) schools of thought both practice ahimsa.

Colorful auras, or lesya, depend on karma to tint this Jain concept with descriptors focused on the five senses such as a flowery fragrance. This concept, sometimes conflated with Ātman, is usually translated as the “soul.”
Destroying the four ghatiya karmas burdening one’s soul allowed Mallinatha and Mahavira to become two of these 24 “ford-makers” who conquered saṃsāra and teach others how to do the same.
answers: tirthankaras (“teer-TUNK-kuh-ruhs”) [prompt on arhats or arihantas or jinas; prompt on kevalis or kevalin; prompt on vitrage]
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, RMP - Other Religion> ~23378~  <Editor: Kevin Thomas

bonuses.leadin: This man meets his lover for the first time as she is carrying “repulsive, alarming yellow flowers,” which he tells her he does not like. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author, the titular lover of Margarita in a Mikhail Bulgakov novel.

The Master writes a book about this procurator, who has headaches and thinks about his dog while interrogating a prisoner. This man follows that prisoner, Yeshua Ha-Notsri, down a “path of moonlight.”
Exact phrase required. The Master says he destroyed his Pontius Pilate novel, but Professor Woland refutes the claim using this three-word phrase.
answers: the Master [accept The Master and Margarita or Master i Margarita]

bonuses.leadin: The only serious outbreak of one of these accusations in the US took place in the town of Massena, New York in 1928. For 10 points each:
parts: Give the two-word term for these accusations that typically allege that Jews are murdering Christians to make Passover matzos.

After the disappearance of Father Thomas in this city in 1840, French consul Ratti Menton sparked a notable blood libel. The New Testament records how the Apostle Paul converted to Christianity while on the road to this Syrian city.

An 1840 blood libel occurred on this Ottoman-ruled island. Philippe Villiers de L’Isle-Adam (“fee-LEEP veel-YAY duh LEEL ah-DOM”) and 600 Knights Hospitaller (“hoss-PIT-ah-lur”) defended this island for six months in 1522.
answers: blood libels [or blood accusation; prompt on ritual murder libel]
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~22871~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

bonuses.leadin: Chopin’s last published piece and only mature chamber work is a G minor sonata for this instrument dedicated to Auguste Franchomme. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this instrument. The operetta composer Victor Herbert inspired Dvořák to write a concerto for this instrument in B minor.

Franchomme transcribed a piece in this genre by Chopin often nicknamed “Cello” for its heartsick left-hand melody. Chopin’s other pieces in this didactic genre include ones nicknamed “Black Key” and “Revolutionary.”
Franchomme and Chopin jointly wrote a Grand duo concertant for cello and piano based on themes from this Jewish composer’s opera Robert le diable (“roh-BAIR le dee-AHB-luh”).

parts: The “high water mark of the Confederacy” was reached on Cemetery Ridge during this 1863 battle in southern Pennsylvania.
The northernmost fighting on land was a series of raids in St. Albans in this state. This state’s soldiers were sometimes referred to by the name of a militia led earlier by Ethan Allen.

The last shot of the war was fired in the Bering Sea by the Shenandoah, one of these ships targeting Union merchant ships. The Alabama Claims were made in response to one of these ships that targeted logistics.
answers: Vermont [or VT] (The militia was the Green Mountain Boys.)
commerce raiders [prompt on raiders; prompt on a sloop or a sailing ship with “what was its purpose?”]

bonuses.leadin: H2 and N2 are the only homonuclear diatomic gases whose highest-occupied MO is this kind of orbital. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these low-energy molecular orbitals that form when atomic orbitals overlap constructively. They are not represented by an asterisk.
The six bonding electrons in nitrogen gas form one of these very strong covalent bonds made up of a sigma bond and two pi bonds.

In organic molecules with this property, the bonding pi orbitals are completely filled and the antibonding pi orbitals are completely empty. The pi orbital energies coincide with the vertices when molecules with this property are inscribed in a circle.
answers: bonding molecular orbitals [or bonding MOs; prompt on chemical bonds or covalent bonds; reject “antibonding” or “nonbonding” orbitals]
bonuses.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Chemistry> ~22185~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

bonuses.leadin: Neith’s association with this region is exemplified by her patronage of Sais and her depictions wearing the red-crown, or Deseret. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this region whose half of the “Two Ladies” was the cobra goddess Wadjet, whereas its southern neighbor revered the vulture Nekhbet.

A ruined Lower Egyptian city near modern-day Zagazig once revered this lion goddess whose visage became more nurturing over time, in contrast to Sekhmet. This goddess’s iconography showed her attacking Apep with a knife.
The Greeks prescribed Bast the title “Soul of [this deity]” due to an invented sibling relationship with Horus. This deity was the wife of Osiris.
answers: Lower Egypt [accept Ta-Mehu; prompt on Egypt; prompt on the Nile Delta; do not accept or prompt on “Upper Egypt”]
bonuses.metadata: Forrest Weintraub, RMP - World Mythology> ~22934~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

parts: Give this title trait of a play in which a man named Sizwe Banzi adopts the identity of a permit worker.
Sizwe Banzi is Dead is a play by this South African author of Master Harold...and the Boys.

In a charge for his actors, Rotimi described his play’s audience as a “wait-and-get” group defined by a type of these objects. Sizwe Banzi goes to Styles’s workplace to obtain one of these objects to send to his wife.
answers: dead [or being dead; accept not being alive; accept living dead; accept Hopes of the Living Dead or Sizwe Banzi is Dead]
photographs [accept Polaroid or Polaroid audience; prompt on pictures; reject “identity card” or “ID”]

bonuses.leadin: This technique is done using chemicals like Hoechst (“HOESHT”) 33342 to detect DNA by fluorescence microscopy. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this common practice in histology. Crystal violet is used in a form of this technique invented by Hans Christian Gram to classify bacteria.
Hoechst dyes can stain both living cells and tissues that have undergone this process. This process kills cells, but preserves their organelles, and attaches them to a microscope slide.
Hoechst dyes attach to this structural feature of DNA. That’s odd, because transcription factors tend to avoid this side of the double helix, which is narrower than its complement in B-DNA.
bonuses.metadata: David Bass, Science - Biology> ~22598~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

bonuses.leadin: A 1971 paper rejects the “extreme view” of this action by arguing that “killing” is not always less morally permissible than “letting die.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this subject of a “defense” by Judith Jarvis Thomson, which considers an unconscious violinist that only you have the right blood type to help.
Thomson expanded on the “killing” versus “letting die” distinction in a paper on this thought experiment, in which one can pull a lever to kill one person instead of five.
The trolley problem was introduced in this philosopher’s paper “The Problem of Abortion and the Doctrine of Double Effect.” This virtue ethicist wrote Natural Goodness.
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, RMP - Philosophy> ~23520~ <Editor: Vincent Du

bonuses.leadin: Sore loser laws prevent losers of these elections from running in general elections as independents or under a different party. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these elections which, along with caucuses, determine the major-party candidates of presidential elections.

Sore loser laws are designed in part to limit this electoral effect common in first-past-the-post systems, in which a third-party candidate can change the outcome of an election by taking votes from a closely-aligned major party candidate.
While distinct from running under two parties, this electoral practice of multiple parties nominating the same candidate is also outlawed in many states.
answers: spoiler effect [accept vote splitting or split vote; accept spoiling an election; accept Nader effect; reject “split-ticket” voting]

bonuses.leadin: According to the book The Bookshop of the World, during this period, 10 times more books were produced per capita than in France or Spain. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this period, also the subject of Simon Schama’s The Embarrassment of Riches. This period’s end is traditionally dated to the “Disaster Year” of 1672.
These structures reduced the cost of transporting books during the Dutch Golden Age. One of these projects in the US was dubbed “Clinton’s Folly.”

The prominent Dutch House of Elzevir published a noted New Testament in this language, whose Koine (“koy-NAY”) variety was used to produce the Septuagint (“sep-TOO-uh-jint”) and was spoken during the Hellenistic period.
answers: Dutch Golden Age [or Gouden Eeuw; or Netherlands Golden Age; or Dutch Miracle; prompt on Golden Age]
canals [or artificial waterways] (The second clue refers to the Erie Canal.)
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - European - 1500-1900> ~20764~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

bonuses.leadin: A ratio named for this process is approximately 10-to-1 for internal combustion engines, but 20-to-1 for diesel engines. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this process that occurs in the third and fourth stages of the Carnot cycle. Diesel engines use this process instead of spark plugs to ignite fuel.
Air is compressed in engines by the strokes of these devices. V8 engines are named for having eight of these devices arranged in a “V” shape.

An engine’s compression ratio is calculated from combustion chamber volumes when the piston is at “top” and “bottom [this location].” This two-word term describes the upper and lower extents of a piston.
answers: dead center [accept top dead center or bottom dead center; prompt on center]
bonuses.metadata: Benjamin Chapman, Science - Engineering and Miscellaneous> ~22113~ <Editor: David Bass

bonuses.leadin: Many members of this movement worked out of the newly-built West Tenth Street Studio Building in New York City. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this nineteenth-century American landscape art movement named for a landform and led by Thomas Cole.
This Hudson River School artist depicted Cole alongside his friend William Cullen Bryant in the Catskill Mountains in his painting Kindred Spirits.

Another Hudson River School artist, Albert Bierstadt, studied for three years at this German city’s Academy. This city is also renowned for its School of Photography, where Andreas Gursky captured two views of the Rhine.

bonuses.leadin: At the opening of a play, this character discovers King Antiochus has been having an incestuous relationship with his daughter. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this “Prince of Tyre” whose namesake play has been attributed partially to Shakespeare by critical scholarship.
Pericles was lambasted in an ode as a “mouldy tale” by this British playwright of Volpone (“vol-poh-NAY”) and The Alchemist.
The incest plot in Pericles was bowdlerized in the Tales from Shakespeare compiled by two members of this family, one of whom wrote the poem “A Farewell to Tobacco” and the collection Essays of Elia.
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, Literature - British - Drama> ~22420~ <Editor: Jim Fan

bonuses.leadin: A political party with this name held power in Zambia for ten years from 2011 to 2021 under the leadership of Michael Sata and Edgar Lungu. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this two-letter acronym that appears at the end of the name of a party that has been led by Emmerson Mnangagwa (“muh-nahn-GAHG-wah”) since a 2017 coup d’etat.

The original Patriotic Front was a paramilitary alliance between the ZANU and ZAPU parties during this country’s Bush War. This former British colony was led by Ian Smith for its entire history from 1965 to 1979.
ZANU-PF’s first leader was this first President of Zimbabwe, who held that position until he was removed from office in 2017.
answers: Republic of Rhodesia [prompt on Zimbabwe by asking “by what name was it known at the time?”]
bonuses.metadata: Zac Bennett, History - World - African> ~22896~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about films that prominently feature posters of the actress Rita Hayworth, for 10 points each.
parts: In this film adaptation of a Stephen King novella, the protagonist obtains a poster of Rita Hayworth to hide the escape tunnel that he digs in his cell wall at the title prison.
A woman with amnesia begins calling herself “Rita” after seeing a poster of Rita Hayworth in this 2001 film that stars Naomi Watts as an aspiring actress.
The protagonist of a 1948 film set in this city loses his bicycle while putting up a poster of Rita Hayworth in the street. Federico Fellini’s La dolce vita is also set in this city.
answers: Rome [or Roma] (The unnamed film is Bicycle Thieves by Vittorio De Sica.)
bonuses.metadata: Wonyoung Jang, Fine Arts - Film> ~22268~ <Editor: Chandler West

bonuses.leadin: Robert Eggers used this author’s stories featuring sailors’ speech from Southern Maine as the basis for the accents in the 2019 film The Lighthouse. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author of The Country of the Pointed Firs who is praised by ecofeminists for a story in which Sylvia refuses to tell a hunter the location of a bird.

The Country of the Pointed Firs is often compared to this collection in which Doctor Reefy makes “paper pills” in one story. This collection’s last story “Departure” is centered on the journalist George Willard.
This author of the short story “Paul’s Case” praised Jewett as “the perfection that endures” in the dedication to her novel O Pioneers!
answers: Sarah Orne Jewett (The unnamed story is “A White Heron.”)
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, Literature - American - Short Fiction> ~22188~ <Editor: Chandler West

bonuses.leadin: This effect has been leveraged by musicians through the double-tracking of vocals that are then panned hard to either side of the audio field. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this psychoacoustic effect named for a German engineer in which two similar sounds separated by a slight delay are perceived by the listener as one fuller sound.

The Haas effect is often replicated through this phenomenon, often confused with delay. This persistence of sound after the initial signal is also referred to as “echo” at higher reflection times and occurs in large performance halls.
The Haas Effect is best heard in this multi-channel form of audio playback which is contrasted with mono and used in cars to send sound through different speakers.
answers: Haas effect [accept precedence effect; accept law of the first wavefront; prompt on overdubbing or layering]
bonuses.metadata: Wonyoung Jang, Fine Arts - Miscellaneous> ~22276~ <Editor: Ganon Evans
